ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed the skills to do single variable calculus
I learned BC calculus: derivatives, integrals, etc.
This class teaches you the basics of calc 2 - take it if you need math
I learned how to take detailed notes and study for exams, as well as learning a lot of math.

I learned how to approach calculus in a different, and at times, more creative way. It challenged my analytical skills as well as my ability to seek help though external resources. Also improved my discipline and determination to complete assignments.
I learned how to solve complex calculus problems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great at addressing questions
The course was good at providing a lot of practice problems, but the notes were not very clear, so I kinda had to teach myself the material.

The strength of this course is the peer tutor system run throughout the week which helps students complete their p-sets. The peer tutors were willing to take the time to explain complex concepts and problems. The weaknesses of this course include the non-engaging 75-minute lectures, really time-consuming P-sets, unhelpful exam review sessions and practice tests, and challenging exams. The p-sets often had questions unrelated to any testable concepts, which is excellent for learning but bad for overall exam preparation. The course material was also rushed, and the exam schedule did not match the pace at which all the material could be taught.
The exams were way harder than anything we did in class and the classes were not that useful

This course is very heavy in terms of a course designed for first years mainly. It has a decent structure followed by the professors and has many resources available for the students to take advantage of. However, a main weakness with this course are the explorations assigned through canvas and due before each class. These explorations are more confusing when the topics themselves are confusing to learn solely though reading the material. The explorations would definitely be more helpful if they were due after class as a check and extra practice for the topics covered that week.
The peer tutoring that was available daily was a strength. I think there wasn't enough practice available other than problem sets, so an improvement could be more in class practice problems.
Very structured - wish it was more applications-based.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes
yes, make sure you keep up with your work and stay up to date on the material.

Do not take this course unless it is a prerequisite course for your major. Inevitably, most STEM majors or people with a wide range of interests will have to take this course but be prepared for the challenge ahead of you.
Not unless you need it
Probably, since the course is virtually a necessity for any STEM focused major. It was difficult, and a lot of work, but no more so than any number of other courses.

I would recommend this course for students who have the discipline to learn and seek help outside of the classroom. It is a very taxing course although the concepts are not that difficult in retrospect. The course requires a lot of outside help in order to succeed.
Good course for developing a foundation in calc 2. Fast paced but very doable.
I would recommend this course if a student needs to take it for a major or for a requirement, but otherwise it is pretty difficult and time consuming.
If you don't know calculus, a must-take! (Not that you have many options.)
